The said suit was decreed and an execution petition was filed by the first respondent decree-holder for executing the said decree. In the said execution proceeding property belonging to the appellant was put to auction for realisation of the decretal amount. The validity of the said auction came to be questioned by the appellant by filing an execution application praying therein for setting aside the court auction-sale. The said application was dismissed by the execution court, against which an appeal was preferred by the appellant which was also dismissed by a Single Judge of the Madras High Court. A letters patent appeal thereagainst purported to be in tenns of clause 15 of the Letters Patent of the Madras High Court was filed by the appellant which was dismissed by a Full Bench of the Madras High Court holding that in terms of Section 104(2) CPC, an appeal against an order passed by the appellate court under Order 43 Rule l(j) CPC read with Section 104, was not maintainable. A certificate of fitness, however, in terms of Article 133 of the Constitution was granted by the said Full Bench. When the matter was placed before a Division Bench of the Supreme Court, it noticed a conflict of opinion between decisions of two-Judge Benches of the Supreme Court in New Kenilworth Hotel, (1997) 3 SCC 462 and Resham Singh Pyara Singh, (1996) 1 SCC 49 on the one hand, and a Constitution Bench decision in Guiab Bai case, (1966) 2 SCR 102, and referred the matter to a Constitution Bench. The matter was placed for disposal before the present Bench. The question that arose before the Supreme Court was whether a letters patent appeal is maintainable against an order passed by a Single Judge of the High Court sitting in appellate jurisdiction. Ltd.~cccc® IONLINEf True Prinf 674 SUPREME COURT CASES (2004) 11 sec Allowing the appeals and remitting the matter back to the High Court, the Supreme Court Held: Per majority§ Section 104 read with Order 43 Rule 1 CPC confers additional powers of appeal to a larger Bench within the High Court. Section 104(2) only bars appeals against orders passed in appeal under the section. Thus Section 104(2) CPC does not bar appeals permitted by any law in force. (Para 19) a The consensus of judicial opinion has been that Section 104(1) CPC specifically saves letters patent appeals and the bar under 104(2) does not apply b to letters patent appeals. (Para 22) Section 104( 1) CPC contemplates three types of orders from which appeals are provided, namely, (J) orders enumerated therein, (2) appeals otherwise expressly provided in the body of the Code, and (3) appeals provided by any law for the time being in force. It is not disputed that an appeal provided under the Letters Patent of the High Court is an appeal provided by a law for the time being in force. (Para 29) It is a well-established rule of interpretation that if one interpretation leads to C a conflict whereas another interpretation leads to a harmonious reading of the section, then an interpretation which leads to a harmonious reading must be adopted. In the guise of giving a purposive interpretation one cannot interpret a d section in a manner which would lead to a conflict between two sub-sections of the same section. (Para 15) As a letters patent appeal is expressly saved by Section 104(1), sub-section (2) cannot apply to such an appeal. Section 104 CPC has to be read as a whole. Merely reading sub-section (2) by ignoring the saving clause in sub-section (1) would lead to a conflict between the two sub-sections. Read as a whole and on well-established principles of interpretation it is clear that sub-section (2) can e only apply to appeals not saved by Section 104(1). The finality provided by sub- section (2) only attaches to orders passed in appeal under Section 104 i.e. those orders against which an appeal under "any other law for the time being in force" is not pennitted. Section 104(2) would not thus bar a letters patent appeal. Effect must also be given to legislative intent of introducing Section 4 CPC and the words "by any law for the time being in force" in Section 104(1). This was done to give effect to the Calcutta, Madras and Bombay views that Section 104 did not f bar a Letters Patent. As appeals under "any other law for the time being in force" undeniably include a letters patent appeal, such appeals are now specifically saved. Section 104 must be read as a whole and harmoniously. (Paras 30, 14 and 15) A specific exclusion may be clear from the words of a statute even though no specific reference is made to Letters Patent. But where there is an express saving in the statute/section itself, then general words to the effect that "an appeal would g not lie" or "order will be final" are not sufficient. In such cases, as in Section 104(1) i.e. where there is an express saving, there must be an express exclusion. A letters patent appeal cannot be ousted by implication, but the right of an appeal under the Letters Patent can be taken away by an express provision in an appropriate legislation. It is not being said that a general exclusion would never oust a letters patent appeal. However, when Section 104(1) CPC specifically saves a letters patent appeal then the only way such an appeal could be excluded is by express mention in Section 104(2) that a letters patent appeal is also prohibited. It is for this reason that Section 4 CPC provides as it does. (Paras 30 and 22) From Section 100-A CPC, as inserted in 1976, it can be seen that when the legislature wanted to exclude a letters patent appeal it specifically did so. Again from Section 100-A, as amended in 2002, it can be seen that the legislature has provided for a specific exclusion. It must be stated that now by virtue of Section 100-A no letters patent appeal would be maintainable in the facts of the present case. However, it is an admitted position that the law which would prevail would be the law at the relevant time. At the relevant time neither Section 100-A nor Section 104(2) barred a letters patent appeal. The words used in Section 100-A are not by way of abundant caution. By the Amendment Acts of 197 6 and 2002 a specific exclusion is provided as the legislature knew that in the absence of such words a letters patent appeal would not be barred. The legislature was aware that it had incorporated the saving clause in Section 104(1) and incorporated Section 4 CPC. Thus now a specific exclusion was provided. (Para 30) Therefore, on facts, the appeal under clause 15 of the Letters Patent of Madras High Court is an appeal provided by a law for the time being in force. Therefore, the finality contemplated by Section 104(2) did not attach to an appeal passed under such law. (Para 31) Guiab Bai v. Puniya, (1966) 2 SCR 102: AIR 1966 SC 637,followed Shah Babula! Ltd.~cccc® IONLINEf True Prinf 676 SUPREME COURT CASES (2004) 11 sec Per minority§§ For proper construction of Section 104 CPC vis-a-vis clause 15 of the Letters Patent, it is necessary to ascertain the intention of Parliament. A right of a appeal is a creature of statute and the said right, thus, can only be enjoyed if law confers the same. The legislature thought it fit to confer such a right upon the suitor by reason of Section 104 read with Order 43 CPC. When a right is granted under a statute, a further right of appeal must receive such construction which would give effect to the plain meaning of the words emphasised in the section. Therefore, the saving clause contained in Section 104(1) must be literally construed having regard to the fact that the provisions other than specifically b mentioned in Order 49 of the Code are applicable even on the original side of the High Court. (Paras 68, 59 and 95) When a right of appeal is conferred under a special statute, the bar contained in Section 104(2) CPC would not operate and a right of intra-court appeal provided for in the Letters Patent of the High Court subject to any statutory embargo would, thus, be saved. (Para 56) c When the special statute confers a right of appeal, such right is saved, but by reason thereof no right of appeal is created under Section 104. Finality clause contained in a statute, unless attached to an order passed in appeal, would not take away the right of appeal expressly provided for under the special statute. If a right of appeal is created by a statute, the same would be governed by the terms thereof. Appeals under the special statute are saved only to the extent a contrary d provision is not contained in other provisions thereof. [Paras 55, 148(1), (4), 56 and 62] An appealable order may be passed by a High Court in its original jurisdiction. A right to maintain an appeal indisputably would depend upon the subject-matter thereof. Having regard to Section 4 read with Order 49 CPC only certain provisions of the Code as specified therein would have no application on the original side of the High Court. In the event an appealable order is passed by e the High Court in its original jurisdiction, an appeal may be maintainable both under Section 104 CPC as also under clause 15 of the Letters Patent of the Madras High Court, although the said right arises from two different sources. An appeal under the Letters Patent may, therefore, be availed of in relation to an order which has not been specifically provided for under Section 104(1), which is otherwise a judgment within the meaning thereof. The saving clause contained f in Section 104(1) does not go further and say that even an order passed in appeal from an order specified under Section 104(1) would stand saved. (Paras 57, 61, 63 and 96) If a right of appeal either in terms of Section 104(1) or Letters Patent is availed of, there would not be any further right of appeal from the appellate order in view of Section 104(2), for the simple reason that Letters Patent also provides for only one appeal i.e. from a Single Judge of a High Court to a Division Bench. 9 It may be true that in certain cases letters patent appeals are available even from an appellate order passed by a Single Judge of the High Court to a Division Bench but the same is permissible only when there is no bar thereto and subject to the condition laid down in clause 15 of the Letters Patent itself. In Section 104(2) the statute has used the language in the negative and thus must be construed as mandatory. (Para 68) The purport and object of enacting Section 104(2) CPC is to avoid delay in disposal of the matter. When the statutory intention of minimising the delay in the finality of the decision is manifest, the court must interpret the provisions accordingly. Appeals under Section 104 as also under Order 43 CPC relate to interlocutory orders. By reason of an order passed thereunder the matter may not be finally disposed of. If Parliament in the aforementioned situation thought it fit to cut down a further appeal, no exception thereto can be taken. In any event, even if it be held that by reason of Section 104(2) a party may be deprived of a letters patent appeal in terms of clause 15 of the Madras Letters Patent, he would be at liberty to file, in an appropriate case, an application under Article 136 of the Constitution. Even in a case where the remedy under Section 104( 1) is not availed of, in an appropriate case the order may be questioned in the appeal against the ultimate decree in tenns of Section 105 thereof. (Para 70) The question as to whether a letters patent appeal would be maintainable or not would also depend upon the scheme of the statute.
